title.value: The value of standards for health datasets in artificial intelligence-based applications
title.justification: This is a direct extraction from the title of the paper.
title.quote: The value of standards for health datasets in artificial intelligence-based applications.

extractions.description: This paper aims to explore existing standards, frameworks, and best practices for ensuring adequate data diversity in health datasets used in artificial intelligence (AI) applications, especially focusing on AI as a medical device (AIaMD). The study comprises a systematic review and a survey of stakeholder views to inform the development of consensus-based guidelines for transparent data diversity in health datasets.

type.justification: The study involves a systematic review and thematic analysis of a stakeholder survey, implying that it is based on empirical research methods to gather and analyze data.
type.quote: The study comprises two parts: a systematic review of existing standards, frameworks and best practices for healthcare datasets; and a survey and thematic analysis of stakeholder views of bias, health equity and best practices for artificial intelligence as a medical device.

name.justification: The paper is focused on AI applications in healthcare, specifically AI as a medical device (AIaMD).
name.quote: This Analysis aims to explore existing standards, frameworks and best practices that improve data diversity in health datasets in the context of AIaMD.

name.justification: Health Informatics is a subfield of Healthcare AI that deals with health data, which is a primary focus of this paper.
name.quote: Tackling bias in AI health datasets through the STANDING Together initiative.

name.justification: Medical Ethics is relevant due to discussions on algorithmic bias, health equity, and ethical implications in data representation.
name.quote: we also advocate for a broader view of representativeness in health data, including awareness of the limitations of data collection, data accuracy and ethical concerns around the use of data in minoritized and underserved groups.
